ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to begin creating animation frames.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to stop creating animation frames.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: ANIMATION=START | STOP 
    
Specifies whether to start or stop creating animation frames.

Syntax Description:
START
  specifies to begin creating animation frames.
STOP
  specifies to stop creating animation frames.

Tip: Specify ANIMATION=STOP after you have created the frames for your animation file. 
If ANIMATION=START remains specified, you might unintentionally create an animation file 
for subsequent procedure statements.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to begin creating animation frames.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to stop creating animation frames.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: ANIMDURATION=duration | MIN 
    
Specifies the amount of time that each frame in the animation is held in view. 

Syntax Description:
duration
  specifies the number of seconds to hold an animation frame in view. The number can be any 
  numeric representation (for example, .01, 5, 6.5).

  Defaults:
    0 for GIF frames
    0.1 for SVG pages
  
MIN
  specifies to set the minimum amount of time that a frame is held in view.
  Default: 0.1

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that animation loops continuously repeat.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that animation loops complete one loop.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number of times that an animation loop is continuously repeated. The number must be an integer.     Range: 1–2147483647

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: ANIMLOOP=YES | NO | n
    
Specifies whether the animation loop is played continuously or is played once, or specifies 
a specific number of times that the animation loop is repeated. 

Syntax Description:
  YES
    specifies that animation loops continuously repeat.
  NO
    specifies that animation loops complete one loop. 
  n
    specifies the number of times that an animation loop is continuously repeated. The number must be an integer.
    Range: 1–2147483647

Specifies that each frame in an animation overlays the previous frame. All frames remain in view for 
the duration of the animation.

Specifies that each frame is played sequentially. When a frame is played, it replaces the 
previous frame.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the LOGIN authentication protocol is used.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that no authentication protocol is used.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that the PLAIN authentication protocol is used. The PLAIN authentication protocol encodes  the user ID and password in BASE64 and encodes them as one string.  Note: When you specify PLAIN, you might also need to specify EMAILID and EMAILPW. If you omit  EMAILID, SAS looks up your user ID and uses it. If you omit EMAILPW, no password is used.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: EMAILAUTHPROTOCOL=LOGIN | NONE | PLAIN] 
    
Specifies the authentication protocol for SMTP E-mail.

[Syntax: EMAILHOST=server | (server) | "server" 
    EMAILHOST=('server-1' <options> <'server-2'> <options > …)] 
    
Specifies the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) server that supports e-mail 
access. 

Syntax Description: 
server
  specifies one or more Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) server domain names for your site.
  Range: The maximum number of characters that can be specified for SMTP servers is 1,024.

  Requirement: When more than one server name is specified, the list must be enclosed in parentheses 
  and each server name must be enclosed in single or double quotation marks.
  Note: The system administrator for your site provides this information. 
  
options
  specifies options that are available when you use secure SMTP servers. The following are valid 
  values for options.
    AUTH=|AUTHPROTOCOL=authentication
      specifies the authentication protocol. The following are valid values for auth.
      LOGIN
        specifies that the LOGIN authentication protocol is used. 
      PLAIN 
        specifies that the PLAIN authentication protocol is used.
    PWD=|PASSWORD=|PW=password
      specifies an e-mail logon password. 
    PORT=port-number
      specifies a port number for the SMTP server. 
    SSL | STARTTLS
      specifies either the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) or Transport Layer Security 
    USERID=|ID=username
      specifies the user name that is used to log on to the server.

Syntax: EMAILID=loginid | profile | emailaddress 

Specifies the identity of the individual sending e-mail from within SAS.

Specifies that the FROM e-mail option is required when sending e-mail by using 
either the FILE or FILENAME statements.

Specifies that the FROM e-mail option is not required when sending e-mail by using 
either the FILE or FILENAME statements.

Syntax: EMAILPORT <portnumber>

Specifies the port to which the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) server is attached.

[Syntax: EMAILPW="password"] 
    
Specifies your e-mail login password.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to use the Messaging Application Programming Interface (MAPI) electronic mail interface. This value is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to use the Vendor Independent Mail (VIM) electronic mail interface.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to use the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol email interface.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: EMAILSYS= MAPI | VIM | SMTP] 
    
Specifies the email protocol to use for sending electronic mail.

Identifies the named connection from the metadata user profiles to use as the default 
values for logging in to the SAS Metadata Server.
    
Syntax: METACONNECT="named-connection"
    
where:

"named-connection" is a named connection that is contained in the metadata user profiles.

[Syntax: METAPASS=password] 
    
Sets the default password for the SAS Metadata Server.

[Syntax: METAPORT=number] 
    
Sets the TCP port for the SAS Metadata Server.

[Syntax: METAPROTOCOL=BRIDGE | COM]

Sets the network protocol for communicating with the SAS Metadata Server.

[Syntax: METAREPOSITORY=name] 
    
Sets the name of the default SAS Metadata Repository to use on the SAS Metadata Server.

[Syntax: METASERVER=IP-address] 
    
Sets the internet protocol (IP) address of the SAS Metadata Server.

[Syntax: METASPN=SPN-name]
   
Specifies the service principal name (SPN) for the SAS Metadata Server.

Syntax Description:
SPN-name 
  is the SPN for the principal that runs the metadata server. The maximum length is 256 characters. 
  The following formats are supported for SPN-name: 
  
    SAS/machine-name or SAS/machine-name.company.com. 
    “SAS” is the name of the service and represents the service type.

[Syntax: METAUSER=id] 
   
Sets the default user identification for logging onto the SAS Metadata Server.

Syntax: AUTOSAVELOC="destination"

Specifies the location (pathname) of the Program Editor autosave file. If destination 
contains spaces or is specified in an OPTIONS statement, then enclose destination in 
quotation marks.

Allows certain character combinations to be substituted for special characters that 
may not be on your keyboard.
Does not allow substitutions for certain keyboard characters.

Syntax: FONTSLOC="location"

Specifies the location that contains the SAS fonts that are loaded by some Universal 
Printer drivers.

[Syntax: FORMS=form-name]

Specifies the default form that is used for windowing output.

Specifies that SAS generates an error message and sets the error flag when a _NULL_ 
data set is used in the SORT procedure, or if no BY statement or BY variable is 
specified.

Specifies that SAS ignore the error message and continue processing if the SORT 
procedure attempts to sort a _NULL_ data set or if no BY statement or BY variable 
is specified.

Specifies that during the entire session, SAS attempts to perform automatic, continuous 
clean-up of resources that are not essential for execution.
Specifies that SAS allow the user to choose how to handle an out-of-resource condition.
Enables syntax check mode for multiple steps in the SAS windowing and Explorer environments.

Does not enable syntax check mode for statements that are submitted within the windowing and 
Explorer environments.

Specifies that SAS issue an error message and stop processing if a reference is made to a SAS data 
set that does not exist.

Specifies that SAS ignore the error message LINESIZE=and continue processing if a reference is made to a 
SAS data set that does not exist. The data set reference is treated as if _NULL_ had been specified.

Specifies that SAS abend for most errors (including syntax errors) that would normally cause it to issue
an error message, set OBS=0, and go into syntax-check mode (in batch mode only).

Specifies that SAS handle errors normally, that is, issue an error message, set OBS=0,
and go into syntax-check mode (in batch mode only).
Specifies that SAS terminate BY-group error conditions that would normally cause it to issue an error message.
Specifies that SAS handle BY-group errors normally, that is, by issuing an error message and continuing processing.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to place the SAS program into syntax-check mode when an error occurs in a LIBNAME  or FILENAME statement, or in a LOCK statement in SAS/SHARE software. In addition, the program  or session does not terminate when a %INCLUDE statement fails due to a non-existent file.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to place the SAS program into syntax-check mode when an error occurs in a LIBNAME or  FILENAME statement, or in a LOCK statement in SAS/SHARE software. If the ERRORABEND system  option is set and an error occurs in either a LIBNAME or FILENAME statement, SAS terminates.  In addition, SAS terminates when a %INCLUDE statement fails due to a non-existent file.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: ERRORCHECK=NORMAL | STRICT] 
    
Controls error handling.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the minimum number of observations for which SAS issues error messages to 0.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the maximum number of observations for which SAS issues error messages to the largest signed,  4-byte integer representable in your operating environment.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: ERRORS=n| nK | nM | nG | nT | hexX | MIN| MAX]

Specifies the maximum number of observations for which complete error messages are printed.

Specifies that when SAS cannot find a specified variable format, it generates
an error message and does not allow default substitution to occur.
Replaces missing formats with the w. or $w. default format, issues a note, and continues processing.

Specifies that SAS write to the SAS log a warning for the maximum length for strings in quotation 
marks to the SAS log.

Specifies that SAS does not write a warning for the maximum length for strings in quotation marks 
to the SAS log.

Specifies that SAS either issue a warning and error message, or set _ERROR_=1 and stop processing, 
or both if the error is severe enough to interrupt processing.

Specifies that SAS issue a warning for a variable that is not found, but not set _ERROR_=1 or 
stop processing.

Syntax: APPLETLOC="base-URL" 

Specifies the location of Java applets. The maximum address length is 256 characters.

Syntax: FMTSEARCH=(catalog-specification-1... catalog-specification-n) 

Controls the order in which format catalogs are searched .

[Syntax: PARM=<'>string<'>] 
    
Specifies a parameter string that is passed to an external program.

[Syntax: PARMCARDS=file-ref] 
    
Specifies the file reference to use as the PARMCARDS= file.

Syntax: SASAUTOS=library-specification | (library-specification-1 ... , library-specification-n) 

Specifies one or more locations that contain library members containing SAS macro 
definitions. A location can be a SAS fileref or a host-specific location name 
enclosed in quotation marks.

[Syntax: SYSPARM='character-string'] 
    
Specifies a character string (up to 200 characters) enclosed in quotation marks that 
can be passed to SAS programs.

[Syntax: USER=library-specification]

Specifies the libref or physical name of the default permanent SAS data library.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of UUIDs to acquire (Range: 0-1000). Zero indicates that the  UUID Generator Daemon is not required.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the number of UUIDs to acquire is zero, indicating that the  UUID Generator Daemon is not required.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that 1000 UUIDs at a time should be acquired from the UUID Generator Daemon.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: UUIDCOUNT=n | MIN | MAX]

Specifies the number of UUIDs to acquire each time the UUID Generator Daemon is used.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to perform optimization.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to perform stage 1 optimization. Stage 1 optimization removes redundant instructions, missing  value checks, and repetitive computations for array subscriptions; detects patterns of instructions and  replaces them with more efficient sequences.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to perform stage 2 optimization. Stage 2 performs optimizations that pertain to the SAS register.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies to perform full optimization, which is a combination of stages 1 and 2. This is the default value.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: CGOPTIMIZE=0 | 1 | 2 | 3] 

Specifies the level of optimization to perform during code compilation.
Erases the WORK files at the termination of a SAS session.
Does not erase the WORK files.
Associates a domain suffix with an authentication provider.

Specifies whether batch settings for LINESIZE, OVP, PAGESIZE, and SOURCE are in effect 
when SAS executes.
Specifies that SAS not use the batch settings for LINESIZE=, OVP, PAGESIZE=, and SOURCE.

Specifies that the Select Font window is displayed in the Frame region manager when 
you set the font for a region title. Use the Select Font window to select different 
font families, styles, weights, and point sizes.

Specifies that SAS/AF and SAS/FSP software display a Font Selector window that is 
specific to the operating environment in which the application is executing.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: DFLANG='language', locale
    
Specifies language for international date informats and formats.

These languages are valid values for language:

    English

    French

    Hungarian 
    Italian 
    Japanese 
    Macedonian 
    Norwegian 
    Polish 
    Portuguese 
    Russian 
    Slovenian 
    Spanish 
    Swedish 
    Swiss_French 
    Swiss_German 

locale 
the locale that is specified with the locale system option becomes the active locale.

[Syntax: TRANTAB=(catalog-entries)] 
   
Specifies the translation tables that are used by various parts of SAS. 

Syntax Description:
catalog-entries 
  specifies SAS catalog entries that contain translation tables. If you specify entry-name.type, 
  SAS searches SASUSER.PROFILE first and then SASUSER.HOST.
Causes data set I/O to wait for completion. This is the default.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the number of buffers in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the number of buffers as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the minimum number of buffers to 0, which causes SAS to use the minimum optimal value  for the operating environment. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the number of buffers to the maximum possible number in your operating environment,  up to the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is (2³¹)-1, or approximately 2 billion.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the number of buffers to be allocated for processing SAS data sets.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the logical record length in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value. Default is 256.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the logical record length in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the logical record length as a hexadecimal value.  You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by an X.  For example, the value 2dx sets the logical record length to 45 characters.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies a logical record length of 1.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies a logical record length of 32,767.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: LRECL=n | nK | hexX | MIN | MAX

Specifies the default logical record length to use for reading and writing external files. 

Default:
The shipped default is 32767.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the minimum number of extra index buffers to be allocated to 0. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the number of extra index buffers to be allocated to 10,000.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: IBUFNO=n| nK | nM | nG | nT | hexX  | MIN | MAX

Specifies an optional number of extra buffers to be allocated for navigating an index file.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the page size in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the page size as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the page size to the maximum possible number in your operating environment,  up to the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is (2³¹)-1, or approximately 2 billion.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: BUFSIZE=n| nK | nM | nG | nT |hexX | MIN | MAX]

Specifies the permanent buffer page size for output SAS data sets.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the number of extra page buffers as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the minimum number of extra page buffers to 0.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the number of extra page buffers to 20.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: CBUFNO=n | nK | nM | nG | nT | hexX |MIN | MAX]

Controls the number of extra page buffers to allocate for each open SAS catalog.

[Syntax: CMPLIB=libref.catalog | (libref.catalog-1 ... libref.catalog-n) | (libref.catalogN - libref.catalogM)]

Specifies one or more SAS catalogs containing compiler subroutines to include during program compilation.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the MODEL procedure create two output types for a model, one as a SAS catalog entry  and the other as an XML file. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the output model type is an entry in a SAS catalog.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that the output model type is an XML file.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: CMPLIB=BOTH|CATALOG|XML]

Specifies the output model type for the MODEL procedure.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are uncompressed (fixed-length records).
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records)  by SAS using RLE (Run Length Encoding).
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Same as YES,  but COMPRESS=CHAR is only accepted by Version 7 and later versions.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that the observations in a newly created SAS data set are compressed (variable-length records)  by SAS using RDC (Ross Data Compression).

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: COMPRESS=NO|YES|CHAR|BINARY]

Specifies the type of compression of observations to use for output SAS data sets.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Prohibits certain words as one-level SAS data set names in the DATA statement. They can appear as  two-level names. The following keywords cannot appear as one-level SAS data set names: MERGE,  RETAIN, SET, UPDATE.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Prohibits any keyword that can begin a statement in the DATA step (for example, ABORT, ARRAY, INFILE)  as a one-level data set name in the DATA statement.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Provides no protection against overwriting SAS data sets.

Help.#cdata: Prevents certain errors by controlling the SAS keywords that are allowed in the DATA statement.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Sets the error flag and writes an error message to the SAS log when a variable is missing from an  input data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Writes a warning message to the SAS log when a variable is missing from an input data set  during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: does not write a warning message to the SAS log when a variable is missing from an input data set  during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: DKRICOND=ERROR | WARN|WARNING | NOWARN|NOWARNING]

Specifies the level of error detection to report when a variable is missing from an input data set 
during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Sets the error flag and writes an error message to the SAS log when a variable is missing from an  output data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Writes a warning message to the SAS log when a variable is missing from an output data set  during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: does not write a warning message to the SAS log when a variable is missing from an output data set  during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: DKROCOND=ERROR | WARN|WARNING | NOWARN|NOWARNING]

Specifies the level of error detection to report when a variable is missing for an 
output data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Stops the step and issues an error message to the log immediately. This is the default for batch mode.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Terminates the step, issues an error message to the log, and terminates the SAS session.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: For data files, automatically repairs and rebuilds indexes and integrity constraints, unless the data  file is truncated. You use the REPAIR statement to restore a truncated data set. It issues a warning  message to the log. This is the default for interactive mode. For catalogs, automatically deletes catalog  entries for which an error occurs during the repair process.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: For data files, automatically repairs the data file without the indexes and integrity constraints,  deletes the index file, updates the data file to reflect the disabled indexes and integrity  constraints, and limits the data file to be opened only in INPUT mode.   Restriction: NOINDEX does not apply to damaged catalogs or libraries, only data files.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: For data sets, displays a dialog box that asks you to select the FAIL, ABORT, REPAIR, or NOINDEX  action. For a damaged catalog or library, PROMPT displays a dialog box where you can specify  either FAIL, ABORT, or REPAIR.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the type of action to take when a SAS data set or a SAS catalog is detected as damaged.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Sets the number of the first observation or external file record to process to 1. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the number of the first observation or external file record to process to the maximum number of  observations in the data set, up to the largest eight-byte, signed integer, which is 2⁶³-1, or  approximately 9.2 quintillion observations.

Help.#cdata: Specifies which observation or record SAS processes first.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that fonts are displayed or printed by the operating system and that fonts  are requested in pixels.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that fonts are displayed or printed by the FreeType engine and that fonts  are requested in points. This is the default.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies whether SAS/GRAPH display drivers and image format drivers display or print fonts 
by using the operating system or by using the FreeType engine.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the page size for an index file in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value. The default is 0.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the page size for an index file in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the page size for an index file in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the page size for an index file in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the page size for an index file in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the page size for an index file as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the page size for an index file to the maximum possible number. For IBUFSIZE=,  the value is 32,767 bytes.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: IBUFSIZE=n | nK | nM | nG | nT |hexX | MAX

Specifies the buffer page size for an index file.
Specifies the most recently created data set.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies an integer ranging from 0 to 100 that indicates the JPEG quality factor.  Default is 75.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to set the JPEG quality factor to 0, which has the lowest image quality  and the greatest file compression.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to set the JPEG quality factor to 100, which has the highest image quality  with no file compression.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the JPEG quality factor that determines the ratio of image quality to the level of 
compression for JPEG files produced by the SAS/GRAPH JPEG device driver.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that no warning message is issued. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that a warning message is issued.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that an error message is issued.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: MERGENOBY=NOWARN |WARN | ERROR]

Specifies the type of message that is issued when MERGE processing occurs without 
an associated BY statement.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number to indicate when to stop processing in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number to indicate when to stop processing in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number to indicate when to stop processing in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the number to indicate when to stop processing in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the number to indicate when to stop processing in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the number to indicate when to stop processing as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the minimum number to indicate when to stop processing to 0.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the number to indicate when to stop processing to the maximum number of observations or records,  up to the largest eight-byte, signed integer, which is 263-1, or approximately 9.2 quintillion. This is the default.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the observation that is used to determine the last observation to process, 
or specifies the last record to process.

Specifies that a permanently stored SAS data set can be replaced with another SAS data 
set of the same name.

Specifies that a permanently stored SAS data set cannot be replaced with another SAS 
data set of the same name. This prevents the accidental replacement of existing SAS 
data sets.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to track free space and reuses it whenever observations are added to an  existing compressed data set.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies not to track free space. This is the default.

Help.#cdata: Specifies whether SAS reuses space when observations are added to a compressed SAS data set.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that format and informat names can be up to 32 alphanumeric characters.  This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that creating a format or informat name that is longer than eight characters  results in an error message.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that creating a format or informat name that is longer than eight characters  results in a warning message to remind you that the format or informat cannot be used  with releases before to SAS 9.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the maximum size (32 characters or 8 characters) that user-created format 
and informat names can be before an error or warning is issued.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that variable names can be up to 32 characters in length, must begin with  a letter of the Latin alphabet (A - Z, a - z) or the underscore character, cannot  contain blanks, cannot contain special characters except for the underscore, can  contain mixed-case letters, and cannot be assigned the names of special SAS automatic  variables (such as _N_ and _ERROR_) or variable list names (such as _NUMERIC_,  _CHARACTER_, and _ALL_).
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the variable name follows the same rules as V7, except that the  variable name is uppercase,  as in earlier versions of SAS.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Enables compatibility with other DBMS variable (column) naming conventions, such  as allowing embedded/leading blanks and special/multi-byte characters (not exceeding  32 bytes).

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the rules for valid SAS variable names that can be created and processed 
during a SAS session.

[Syntax: DEVICE=device-driver-specification] 
    
Specifies a terminal device driver for SAS/GRAPH software.

[Syntax: GISMAPS=library-specification| path-to-library]

Specifies the location of the SAS data library that contains SAS/GIS-supplied US 
Census Tract maps.
Displays SAS/GRAPH software output in the GRAPH window.
Displays graphics outside of the windowing environment.

Specifies that ODS styles can be used in the generation of graphs that are stored 
as GRSEG catalog entries. If no style is specified, the default style for the 
given output destination is used. This is the default.

Specifies to not use ODS styles in the generation of graphs that are stored as GRSEG 
catalog entries. Tip: Use NOGSTYLE for compatibility of graphs generated before 
SAS 9.2.

[Syntax: MAPS=location-of-maps] 
    
Specifies the locations (either a libref or a physical path) to search for maps.

Specifies that observations in a data set or data sets are sorted in alphabetic 
or numeric order.

Specifies that observations with the same BY value are grouped together but are 
not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.
Specifies that SAS translate lowercase characters to uppercase.
Specifies that SAS does translate lowercase characters to uppercase.

Specifies that SAS source and data lines be processed as if they were punched card 
images--all exactly 80 bytes long and padded with blanks.
Specifies that SAS source and data lines not be treated as if they were 80-byte card images.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that SAS set the order as month, day, year.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that SAS set the order as month, year, day.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that SAS set the order as year, month, day.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that SAS set the order as year, day, month.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies that SAS set the order as day, month, year.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies that SAS set the order as day, year, month.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies that SAS set the order based on the value that corresponds to the LOCALE= system option  value and is one of the following: MDY | MYD | YMD | YDM | DMY | DYM.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the sequence of month, day, and year when ANYDTDTE, ANYDTDTM, or ANYDTTME informat 
data is ambiguous.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the level of compression. The larger the number, the greater the compression.  Default: 6. Range: 0-9

ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the maximum compression level of 9.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: DEFLATION=n | MIN | MAX]

Specifies the level of compression for device drivers that support the Deflate compression algorithm.

[Syntax: INVALIDDATA='character']

Specifies a character value SAS is to assign to a variable when invalid numeric data are encountered.
It can be a letter (A through Z, a through z), a period (.), or an underscore (_). The default value 
is a period.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the length of statements and data in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the length of statements and data in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the length of statements and data in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the length of statements and data in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the length of statements and data in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the length of statements and data as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the length of statements and data to 0
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the length of statements and data to 2,147,483,647.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the length of statements on each line of a source statement and the length of data on 
lines that follow a DATALINES statement.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the length of statements in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the length of statements in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.

an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE  statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file in multiples of 1 (bytes). Replace n with  an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE  statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes). Replace n  with an integer value.

ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE  statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.

Specifies the length of statements on each line of a source statement from a %INCLUDE statement, 
an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the length of the numeric portion of the sequence field in input source lines or data lines.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that optimization is performed on all PUT functions regardless of any engine that is used  by the query to access the data.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that no optimization is to be performed.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that optimization is performed on all PUT functions whose query is performed by a  SAS/ACCESS engine. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that optimization is performed on all PUT functions whose query is performed by a  SAS/ACCESS engine or a Base SAS engine.

Help.#cdata:
For the SQL procedure, specifies the engine type that a query uses for which optimization is performed 
by replacing a PUT function in a query with a logically equivalent expression.

Specifies that the SQL procedure is to replace references to the DATE, TIME, DATETIME, and TODAY 
functions with their equivalent numeric constant values.

Specifies that the SQL procedure is not to replace references to the DATE, TIME, DATETIME, and TODAY 
functions with their equivalent numeric constant values.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of observations that must be in a table before the SQL procedure considers to  optimize the PUT function in multiples of 1 (bytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of observations that must be in a table before the SQL procedure considers to  optimize the PUT function in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number of observations that must be in a table before the SQL procedure considers to  optimize the PUT function in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the number of observations that must be in a table before the SQL procedure considers to  optimize the PUT function in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the number of observations that must be in a table before the SQL procedure considers to  optimize the PUT function in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the number of observations that must be in a table before the SQL procedure considers to  optimize the PUT function as a hexadecimal value. Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the minimum number of observations that must be in a table before the SQL procedure considers  to optimize the PUT function to 0. A value of 0 indicates that there is no minimum number of  observations required. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the maximum number of observations that must be in a table before the SQL procedure considers  to optimize the PUT function to 2⁶³-1, or approximately 9.2 quintillion.

Help.#cdata:
For the SQL procedure when the SQLREDUCEPUT= system option is set to NONE, 
specifies the minimum number of observations that must be in a table in order for PROC SQL 
to consider optimizing the PUT function in a query.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression in multiples  of 1 (bytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression in multiples  of 1,024 (kilobytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression in multiples  of 1,048,576 (megabytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression in multiples  of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression in multiples  of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression as a hexadecimal  value. Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the minimum number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression to 0.  A value of 0 indicates that there is no minimum number of SAS format values that are required.  This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the maximum number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression to 5,000.

Help.#cdata:
For the SQL procedure when the SQLREDUCEPUT= system option is set to NONE, specifies the maximum 
number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression in order for PROC SQL to 
consider optimizing the PUT function in a query.
Specifies that the SQL procedure can process queries that use remerging of data.
Specifies that the SQL procedure cannot process queries that use remerging of data.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to keep changes that are made by the INSERT and UPDATE statements.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to reverse changes that are made by the INSERT and UPDATE statements as long as reversing  the changes is reliable.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to undo all changes that are made by the INSERT and UPDATE statements, up to the point of  the error. This is the default.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies whether the SQL procedure keeps or discards updated data if errors occur while 
the data is being updated.
Specifies that SAS writes SAS statements to a utility data set in the WORK data library.
Specifies that SAS not write SAS statements to a utility data set in the WORK data library.

[Syntax: YEARCUTOFF=nnnn | YEARCUTOFF=nnnnn]

Specifies the first year of a 100-year span that will be used by date informats and functions to 
read a two-digit year.

Range: 1582-19900 

Default: The shipped default is 1926.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that duplexing is done using the default binding edge.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the long edge as the binding edge for duplexed output.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the short edge as the binding edge for duplexed output.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the binding edge to a printer.

[Syntax: BOTTOMMARGIN=margin-size | "margin-size [margin-unit]"]

Specifies to a printer the size of the margin at the bottom of the page.
Specifies to collate multiple copies for output to a printer.
Specifies not to collate multiple copies for output to a printer. This is the default.
Specifies color printing to a printer, if color printing is supported.
Specifies not to print in color.
[Syntax: COPIES=n] Specifies the number of copies to make when printing to a printer.
Specifies duplexing controls to a printer.
Specifies that duplexing is not performed. This is the default.

[Syntax: LEFTMARGIN=margin-size | "margin-size [margin-unit]"]

Specifies to a printer the size of the margin on the left side of the page.

[Syntax: PAPERDEST=printer-bin-name] 
    
Specifies to a printer the printer bin to receive printed output.

[Syntax: PAPERSIZE=LOCALE | paper_size_name 
    | (width_value<,>height_value) 
    | ('width_value'<,> 'height_value') 
    | ("width_value"<,>"height_value")]

Specifies the paper size to use for printing. 

Syntax Description: 
LOCALE
  specifies to use the value of the LOCALE= system option to determine the value of the PAPERSIZE= 
  option. Depending on the locale, the PAPERSIZE= option is set to either LETTER or A4.
paper_size_name 
  specifies a predefined paper size. 
  Default:Letter or A4, depending on the locale 
  Restriction:The maximum length is 200 characters. 
  Requirements:When the name of a predefined paper size contains spaces, enclose the name 
    in single or double quotation marks. 
  A space is required between the width and the height values if you do not use either single 
    or double quotation marks for values. 

  Tip:Refer to the Registry Editor, or use PROC REGISTRY to obtain a listing of supported 
  paper sizes. Additional values can be added. 

(“width_value”, “height_value”) 
  specifies paper width and height as positive floating-point values. 
  Default:inches 
  Range:in or cm for width_value, height_value

[Syntax: PAPERSOURCE=printer-bin-name] 
    
Specifies to a printer the paper bin to use for printing.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to use plain paper.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to use the standard paper for the printer.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to use glossy paper.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies to use transparent paper.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies a paper type that is defined by the printer.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: PAPERTYPE= PLAIN | STANDARD | GLOSSY | TRANSPARENCY | printer-defined-value] 
    
Specifies to a printer the type of paper to use for printing. Maximum length is 200

[Syntax: PRINTERPATH=('printer-name' <fileref>)] 
    
Controls which Universal Printing printer will be used for printing. If a fileref (optional) is 
specified, it must be defined with a FILENAME statement or external allocation.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to display the Print Abort dialog box when you are printing either to  a file or to the printer.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies not to display the Print Abort dialog box when you are printing either  to a file or to the printer.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to display the Print Abort dialog box only when you are printing to a file.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies to display the Print Abort dialog box only when you are printing to the printer.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: PRTABORTDLGS = BOTH | NEITHER | FILE | PRINTER] 
    
Specifies when to display the Print Abort dialog box.
Specifies to include the Use Forms check box in the Print Setup dialog box.
Specifies to exclude the Use Forms check box from the Print Setup dialog box.

[Syntax: RIGHTMARGIN=margin-size | "margin-size [margin-unit]"]

Specifies the size of the margin at the right side of the page for printed output directed to 
the ODS printer destination.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to display the system/control menu in the windows that are contained  in the main SAS window.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to omit the system/control menu and the minimize, maximize, and close  buttons from the title bar in the windows that are contained in the main SAS window.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to display the minimize and maximize buttons in the windows that are  contained in the main SAS window.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies to omit the minimize and maximize buttons from the windows that are  contained in the main SAS window.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: SASCONTROL=SYSTEMMENU | NOSYSTEMMENU <MINMAX | NOMINMAX>] 
    
Specifies whether the SAS application windows include system/control menus and 
minimize/maximize buttons.

[Syntax: TEXTURELOC=location] 
    
Specifies the location of textures and images that are used by ODS styles. Location can refer 
either to the physical name of the directory or to a URL reference to the directory.

[Syntax: TOPMARGIN=margin-size | "margin-size [margin-unit]"]

Specifies the size of the margin at the top of the page for the ODS printer destination.

Specifies to enable compression of files created by using SAS Universal Printing and 
some SAS/GRAPH files. This is the default.

Specifies to disable compression of files created by using SAS Universal Printing 
and some SAS/GRAPH files.
Specifies that BY lines are printed above each BY group..
Suppresses the automatic printing of BY lines.
Centers SAS procedure output.
Left aligns SAS procedure output.

FORMCHAR='formatting-characters'

Specifies the default output formatting characters. 'formatting-characters' is any 
string or list of strings of characters up to 64 bytes long. If fewer than 64 bytes 
are specified, the string is padded with blanks on the right.

[Syntax: FORMDLIM='delimiting-character'] 
    
Specifies a character to delimit page breaks in SAS output.

Permits SAS procedures to use labels with variables. The LABEL system option must 
be in effect before the LABEL option of any procedure can be used..

Does not allow SAS procedures to use labels with variables. If NOLABEL is specified,
the LABEL option of a procedure is ignored.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the page number in multiples of 1 (n).
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the page number in multiples of 1,024 (nK).

Help.#cdata: [Resets the SAS output page number.

ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Sets the number of lines to skip to 20.

[Syntax: SYSPRINTFONT=("face-name" <weight> <style> <character-set> <point-size> <NAMED "printer-name" | DEFAULT | ALL>)]

Sets the font for the current default printer.

Specifies that the date and the time that the SAS job began are printed at the top of 
each page of the SAS log and any output that is created by SAS.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that SAS encrypts PDF documents using a 128-bit encryption algorithm.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that SAS encrypts PDF documents using a 40-bit encryption algorithm.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that no encryption is performed on PDF documents. This is the default.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the printing permissions for PDF documents.

ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to print PDF documents at a lower resolution for draft-quality documents.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the PDF documents have no print resolution.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to reset the password to open a PDF document to null.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the password to open a PDF document. The quotation marks are optional.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to reset the password used by a PDF document owner to null.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the password for the PDF document owner. The quotation marks are optional.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the password for the PDF document owner and the password to open a PDF document
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the password for the PDF document owner and resets the password to open a PDF document to null.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies to reset both the password used by a PDF document owner and the password to open a PDF document to null.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Specifies to reset the password used by a PDF document owner to null, and specifies a password to open a PDF document.
ToolTips.@ToolTip9: Specifies the password to open a PDF document and the password for the PDF document owner.
ToolTips.@ToolTip10: Specifies the password to open a PDF document and resets the password for the PDF document owner to null.
ToolTips.@ToolTip11: Specifies to reset the password to open a PDF document to null and specifies the password for the PDF document owner.
ToolTips.@ToolTip12: Specifies to reset both the password to open a PDF document and the password for the PDF document owner to null.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the password to use to open a PDF document and the password used by a PDF document owner. 
    
Syntax:
(1) PDFPASSWORD=(OPEN=<">password<"> | OPEN="" < <,> OWNER=<">password<"> | OWNER="">)  
(2) PDFPASSWORD=(OWNER=<">password<"> | OWNER="" <<,> OPEN=<">password<"> | OPEN="">)  
(3) PDFPASSWORD=(OPEN=<">password<"> | OPEN="")  
(4) PDFPASSWORD=(OWNER=<">password<"> | OWNER="" )

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to use the current page layout for Acrobat Reader. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to display one page at a time in the viewing area.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to display all document pages in the viewing area in a single column.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies to display only two pages in the viewing area, with the even pages on the left and  the odd pages on the right.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies to display all pages in the viewing area, two pages side by side. The even pages display  on the left, and the odd pages display on the right.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the page layout for PDF documents.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to use the current page view setting for Acrobat Reader. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to set the page view setting to 100%.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies to view a page using the full extent of the viewing window, maintaining the height  and width aspect ratio.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies to view a page using the full width of the viewing window. The height of the document  is not scaled to fit the page.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies to view a page using the full screen. This option disables the table of contents,  bookmarks, and all other document access aids, such as accessing a specific page.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the page viewing mode for PDF documents.

Specifies that text and graphics from an ODS PDF document can be read by screen readers 
for the visually impaired.

Specifies that text and graphics from an ODS PDF document cannot be read by screen 
readers for the visually impaired.
Specifies that PDF documents can be assembled.
Specifies that PDF documents cannot be assembled. This is the default.
Specifies that PDF document comments cannot be modified. This is the default.
Specifies that PDF document comments can be modified.
Specifies that text and graphics from a PDF document cannot be copied.
Specifies that text and graphics from a PDF document can be copied. This is the default.
Specifies that PDF forms cannot be filled in.
Specifies that PDF forms can be filled in.
Specifies that the contents of a PDF document cannot be changed.
Specifies that the contents of a PDF document can be changed.
Specifies that the date and the time are not printed.

Specifies to include additional information when some SAS procedures
and windows display a listing of files in a SAS data library.
Specifies not to include additional information when files are listed in a SAS data library.
Specifies that SAS updates the date and time in the titles of the SAS log and the listing file..
Specifies that SAS not update the date and time in the titles of the SAS log and the listing file.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of characters in a line.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of characters in a line as a hexadecimal number.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Sets the number of characters in a line to 64.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Sets the number of characters in a line to 256.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: LINESIZE=n | hexX | MIN | MAX

Specifies the line size for the SAS log and for SAS procedure output.

Syntax: MISSING=<'>character<'>

Specifies the character to print for missing numeric values. 

Syntax Description: 
character
  specifies the value to be printed. The value can be any character. Single or double quotation marks are optional.

  Restriction: '00'x is not a valid value for character.

Default: The shipped default is a period (.).

The MISSING= system option does not apply to special missing values such as .A and .Z.
Specifies that SAS print the page number on the first title line of each page of SAS output.
Specifies that SAS not print the page number on the first title line of each page of SAS output.
Specifies that the note that contains the CPU identification number is not written to the SAS log.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to print notes, warnings, CEDA message, and error messages only. N is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to print additional notes pertaining to index usage, merge processing, and sort utilities,  along with standard notes, warnings, CEDA message, and error messages.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the level of detail in messages that are written to the SAS log.
Specifies that SAS writes notes to the SAS log.

Specifies that SAS does not write notes to the SAS log. NONOTES does not suppress error and 
warning messages.

Prints underscores beneath the word in error when SAS encounters an error in a SAS statement.
This option may enable overprinting in some procedures.

Prints dashes on the next line below the word in error when SAS encounters an error 
in a SAS statement.
Prints the entire list of messages to the SAS log.
Prints only the top-level message to the SAS log.
Specifies that SAS writes source statements to the SAS log.
Specifies that SAS not write source statements to the SAS log.
Specifies that SAS writes secondary source statements from included files to the SAS log.
Specifies that SAS not write secondary source statements from included files to the SAS log.

Specifies that the macro processor examine the first word of every windowing environment
command to see whether it is a command-style macro invocation.
Specifies that no check be made for command-style macro invocations.

Specifies that the macro processor examine the first word of every submitted statement
to see whether it is a statement-style macro invocation.
Specifies that no check be made for statement-style macro invocations. This is the default.
Displays the source location of the autocall macros in the log when the autocall macro is invoked.

Prevents the autocall macro source location from being displayed in the log when the autocall macro 
is invoked. NOMAUTOLOCDISPLAY is the default.

Causes the macro processor to search the autocall libraries for a member with the requested name
when a macro name is not found in the WORK library.

Prevents the macro processor from searching the autocall libraries when a macro name is not found 
in the WORK library.

Syntax: MCOMPILENOTE=<NONE | NOAUTOCALL | ALL>

Issues a NOTE to the log upon successful compilation of a macro.

Specifies that SAS issues a warning message when a macro-like name does not match 
a macro keyword.

Issues no warning messages when the macro processor cannot match a macro reference 
to a compiled macro.

Routes output produced by the MPRINT option to an external file. This is useful 
for debugging.
Does not route MPRINT output to an external file.
Allows new definitions of macros.
Disallows new definitions of macros.
Displays the macro execution information in the log when the macro is invoked.
Does not display the macro execution information in the log when the macro is invoked.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the maximum size macro to be executed in memory available in bytes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the maximum size macro to be executed in memory available in kilobytes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the maximum size macro to be executed in memory available in megabytes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the maximum size macro to be executed in memory available in gigabytes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the maximum size macro to be executed in memory available in terabytes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the maximum size macro to be executed in memory by a hexadecimal number followed by an X.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies the minimum size macro to be executed in memory. Minimum value is 0.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Specifies the maximum size macro to be executed in memory. Maximum value is 2,147,483,647.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the maximum macro size that can be executed in memory.

Specifies that the SORT procedure verifies if the observations in the data set are 
sorted by the variables specified in the BY statement.

Specifies that the SORT procedure is not to verify if the observations in the data 
set are sorted. This is the default.

Causes the macro processor to recognize and evaluate both the mnemonic operator IN 
or the special character # as a logical operator in expressions.

Causes the macro processor to recognize both the mnemonic operator IN and the special 
character # as regular characters.

Enables you to redefine existing macro definitions that are stored in a catalog in the 
WORK library.

Prevents you from redefining existing macro definitions that are stored in a catalog in 
the WORK library.
Specifies the character to be used as the delimiter for the macro IN operator.

Causes the macro processor to trace its execution and to write the trace information 
to the SAS log. This option is a useful debugging tool.
Does not trace execution. Use this option unless you are debugging macros.
Allows the macro nesting information to be displayed in the MLOGIC output in the SAS log.
Prevents the macro nesting information from being displayed in the MLOGIC output in the SAS log.

Displays the SAS statements that are generated by macro execution. This is useful 
for debugging macros.
Does not display SAS statements that are generated by macro execution.

Allows the macro nesting information to be displayed in the MPRINT output in the 
SAS log.

Prevents the macro nesting information from being displayed in the MPRINT output 
in the SAS log.

Searches the autocall libraries for an undefined macro name each time an attempt 
is made to invoke the macro.
Searches the autocall libraries only once for a requested macro name.

Searches for stored compiled macros in a catalog in the SAS data library referenced 
by the SASMSTORE= option.
Does not search for compiled macros.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the amount of memory as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the amount of memory that is available to the minimum setting, which is 0.  This value causes all macro variables to be written to disk.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the amount of memory that is available to the maximum setting.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: MSYMTABMAX= n | nK | nM | nG | nT |hexX | MIN | MAX] 

Specifies the maximum amount of memory that is available to macro variable 
symbol tables.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the maximum macro variable size in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the maximum macro variable size in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the maximum macro variable size as a hexadecimal value.  Replace hex with an actual hexadecimal value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Sets the macro variable size to the minimum setting, which is 0 bytes. This value  causes all macro variables to be written to disk.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Sets the macro variable size to the maximum setting, which is 65,534 bytes.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: MVARSIZE= n | nK | nM | nG | MAX] 
    
Specifies the maximum size for macro variables that are stored in memory.

[Syntax: SASMSTORE=libref] 
    
Specifies the libref of a SAS data library that contains a catalog of stored, 
compiled SAS macros.

Controls whether SAS issues a warning message when a defined macro variable reference 
does not match a macro variable.

Issues no warning messages when the macro processor cannot match a macro variable 
reference to an existing macro variable.
Specifies to write real-time and CPU time to the SAS log.
Specifies not to write real-time and CPU time to the SAS log.

Displays the results of resolving macro variable references. This option is useful 
for debugging.
Does not display results of resolving macro variable references.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Removes duplicates based on all the variables that are present in the data set.  This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Removes duplicates based on only the variables remaining after the DROP= and  KEEP= data set options are processed.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies whether the SORT procedure removes duplicate variables based on all variables in a data set 
or the variables that remain after the DROP or KEEP data set options have been applied.

Specifies that observations with identical BY variable values are to retain the same 
relative positions in the output data set as in the input data set.

Specifies that no resources be used to control the order of observations with identical 
BY variable values in the output data set.

Help.#cdata:
[SORTSEQ=collation-sequence] 
   
Specifies a language-specific collation sequence for the SORT procedure to use in the 
current SAS session. 

Syntax Description: 
collating-sequence 
  specifies the collating sequence that the SORT procedure is to use in the current 
  SAS session. Valid values can be user-supplied, or they can be one of the following: 
  
    ASCII 
    DANISH (alias NORWEGIAN) 
    EBCDIC 
    FINNISH 
    ITALIAN 
    NATIONAL 
    POLISH 
    REVERSE

Help.#cdata: Specifies the amount of memory that is available to the SORT procedure.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the amount of memory in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
