Help.#cdata:
Specifies a limit on the amount of memory that is available for data summarization procedures when 
class variables are active.

[Syntax: ARMAGENT=module]

Specifies another vendor's ARM agent, which is an executable module that contains 
a vendor's implementation of the ARM API.

[Syntax: ARMLOC=fileref | filename]

Specifies the location of the ARM log, where 'fileref' is a SAS name that is associated 
with the physical location of the ARM log, and 'filename' is the physical location of the 
log.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that no internal SAS processing transactions are written to the ARM log.  This is the default setting.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that all available internal SAS processing transactions are written to the ARM log.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Collects SAS data set I/O processing information.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Collects IOM Server processing information.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Collects SAS procedure and DATA step processing information.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Collects SAS OLAP Server session information.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: ARMSUBSYS=(ARM_NONE | ARM_ALL | subsystem1 <item1 <item2 <...> > > <, subsystem2 <item1 <item2 <...> > >><OFF>)]

Enables and disables the ARM subsystems that determine the internal SAS processing transactions 
to be logged.

ARM_NONE specifies that no internal SAS processing transactions are written to the ARM log. This 
is the default setting.

ARM_ALL specifies that all available internal SAS processing transactions are written to the ARM log.

subsystem specifies an ARM subsystem, which is a group of internal SAS processing transactions that '
are to be written to the ARM log.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to keep mathematical operations that do not affect the outcome  of a statement.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to remove mathematical operations that do not affect the outcome  of a statement.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that analytic derivatives are computed for user defined functions.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that no analytic derivatives are computed for user defined functions.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies to check for array boundary problems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies not to check for array boundary problems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies to check for missing values in the data.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Specifies not to check for missing values in the data.
ToolTips.@ToolTip9: Specifies to handle exceptions at an operation boundary.
ToolTips.@ToolTip10: Specifies to handle exceptions at a statement boundary.
ToolTips.@ToolTip11: Specifies that the compiler is to optimize the machine language code  by using the (NOEXTRAMATH NOMISSCHECK NOPRECISE NOGUARDCHECK NOFUNCDIFFERENCING)  optimization values. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip12: Specifies that the compiler is not set to optimize the machine language code by using the  (EXTRAMATH MISSCHECK PRECISE NOGUARDCHECK FUNCDIFFERENCING) optimization values.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: CMPOPT=optimization-value | (optimization-value-1 ... optimization-value-n) 
  | "optimization-value-1 ... optimization-value-n"| ALL | NONE]

Specifies the type of code generation optimizations to use in the SAS language compiler.
Specifies to set the value of CMPOPT to ALL.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Is the number of CPUs that SAS will assume are available for use by thread-enabled applications.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Returns the number of physical processors that are associated with the operating system where  SAS is executing.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: CPUCOUNT = 1-1024|ACTUAL]

Specifies the number of processors that the thread-enabled applications should assume
will be available for concurrent processing. 

Defaults:
Under UNIX and Windows, if a system has four or more processors, the default value is 4. 
If a system has fewer than four processors, the default is ACTUAL.

Under z/OS, the default is ACTUAL.
Specifies to use threaded processing for SAS applications that support it.
Specifies not to use threaded processing for running SAS applications that support it.
Specifies that encryption is required.
Specifies that encryption is not required, but is optional.

[Syntax: NETENCRYPTALGORITHM=algorithm | ("algorithm-1"... "algorithm-n")] 
   
Specifies the algorithm(s) that can be used for encrypting data that is transferred between 
a client and a server across a network.

[Syntax: NETENCRYPTKEYLEN=0 | 40 | 128] 
    
Specifies the key length to use for encrypted client/server data transfers.

[Syntax: SSLCALISTLOC="file-path"] 
    
Specifies the location of digital certificates for trusted certification authorities (CA).

[Syntax: SSLCERTISS="issuer-of-digital-certificate"] 

Specifies the name of the issuer of the digital certificate that SSL should use.

[Syntax: SSLCERTLOC="file-path"] 
    
Specifies the location of the digital certificate that is used for authentication.

[Syntax: SSLCERTSERIAL="serial-number"] 
    
Specifies the serial number of the digital certificate that SSL should use.

[Syntax: SSLCERTSUBJ="subject-name"] 
    
Specifies the subject name of the digital certificate that SSL should use.
Specifies that the server should perform client authentication.
Specifies that the server should not perform client authentication.
Specifies that CRLs are checked when digital certificates are validated.
Specifies that CRLs are not checked when digital certificates are validated.

[Syntax: SSLCRLLOC="file-path"] 
   
Specifies the location of a Certificate Revocation List (CRL).

[Syntax: SSLPVTKEYLOC="file-path"] 
   
Specifies the location of the private key that corresponds to the digital certificate.

[Syntax: SSLPVTKEYPASS="password"] 
    
Specifies the password that SSL requires for decrypting the private key.

Specifies the height of the viewport unless the SVG output is embedded in another 
SVG output; specifies the value of the height attribute of the outermost <svg> 
element in the XML file.
Specifies to display the paging control buttons in the SVG document.

Specifies not to display the paging control buttons in the SVG document. 
This is the default.

[Syntax: SVGTITLE="title" | "" | "] 
    
Specifies the title in the title bar of the SVG output; specifies the value of the 
<title> element in the XML file.

"" | " specifies to reset the title to empty.

[Syntax: SVGVIEWBOX="min-x min-y width height" | none | "" | "] 
    
Specifies the coordinates, width, and height that are used to set the viewBox attribute 
on the outermost <svg> element, which enables SVG output to scale to the viewport. 

"" | " specifies to reset the width and height of the viewBox to the width and height 
of the paper size for the SVG printer.

[Syntax: SVGWIDTH="number-of-units<unit-of-measure>" | "" | " ] 
    
Specifies the width of the viewport unless the SVG output is embedded in another SVG output; 
specifies the value of the width attribute of the outermost <svg> element in the XML file. 

"" | " specifies to reset the width to the default value of 800 pixels.

[Syntax: SVGX="number-of-units<unit-of-measure>" | "" | " ] 
    
Specifies the x-axis coordinate of one corner of the rectangular region into which an 
embedded <svg> element is placed; specifies the x attribute on the outermost <svg> 
element in an XML file. 

"" | " specifies to reset the x attribute to 0 on the <svg> element and the x-axis 
coordinate for embedded SVG to 0.

[Syntax: SVGY="number-of-units<unit-of-measure>" | "" | " ] 
    
Specifies the y-axis coordinate of one corner of the rectangular region into which an 
embedded <svg> element is placed; specifies the y attribute on the outermost <svg> 
element in an XML file. 

"" | " specifies to reset the y attribute to 0 on the <svg> element and the y-axis 
coordinate for embedded SVG to 0.

Enables syntax check mode for statements that are submitted within a non-interactive 
or batch SAS session.

Does not enable syntax check mode for statements that are submitted within a non-interactive 
or batch SAS session.

[Syntax: DQLOCALE=(locale1 <locale2 ...localeN>)]
    
Specifies an ordered list of locales. You must specify at least one locale.

[Syntax: DQOPTIONS=(label1=value1<, label2=value2..., labelN=valueN>)] 
    
Specifies SAS session parameters for data quality programs.
    
  labelN=valueN 
  specifies a data quality option keyword and a value for the option. The following 
  keywords are available:

  DQSRVPROTOCOL=WIRELINE 
  specifies the Wireline protocol, which is required in the z/OS operating environment 
  for DataFlux Integration Servers version 8.1.1 or newer.

  TRANSCODE=IGNORE | WARN 
  specifies that transcoding errors will not end SAS processing. IGNORE prevents the 
  appearance of transcoding warning messages in the SAS log.

[Syntax: DQSETUPLOC=`file-specification' | `path-specification'] 
    
Specifies the location of the SAS Data Quality Server setup file or the root directory 
of the Quality Knowledge Base.

Specifies that SAS write to the SAS log a complete list of computer resources that 
were used for each step and for the entire SAS session.

Specifies that SAS not write a complete list of computer resources to the SAS log. 
    
NOFULLSTIMER is the default.
Specifies to minimize the main SAS window immediately.
Restores the main SAS window immediately.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies memory cache is off.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies not to add any new files to the cache. Reads and writes to files already  in the cache continue as if MEMCACHE is on.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies memory cache is on. Memory is used as a SAS file cache.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: MEMCACHE= 0 | 1 | 4]

Specifies to use the memory-based libraries as a SAS file cache. 

When the MEMCACHE system option is 4 or 1, SAS file cache places data in memory 
as it is processed. This data is then available for future references by SAS. Files 
in the cache are kept until SAS is shut down, caching is terminated, or more space 
is required for new files. Memory is reclaimed on a least recently used basis. Cached 
data is written to permanent storage. You can control which SAS libraries use the 
cache by using the MEMCACHE system option in the OPTIONS statement. Memory usage can 
be monitored using the performance tools.

Specifies to close the command prompt window automatically. 
    
When executed on a workstation using the DI-Atlantis
build module, a command window opens to execute the
build module followed by a second command window to launch
DI-Diver to view the model just created. DI-Diver should be
launched only after the model has been created. All this should
happen automatically without your intervention.

Specifies that the SAS System will wait for the application
to finish.
    
When executed on a workstation using the DI-Atlantis
build module, a command window opens to execute the
build module followed by a second command window to launch
DI-Diver to view the model just created. DI-Diver should be
launched only after the model has been created. All this should
happen automatically without your intervention.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that member name must be compatible with the current rules:    o can be up to 32 bytes in length.    o must begin with a letter of the Latin alphabet (A - Z, a - z) or the underscore character.      Subsequent characters can be letters of the Latin alphabet, numerals, or underscores.    o cannot contain blanks.    o cannot contain special characters except for the underscore.    o can contain mixed-case letters; however, SAS normalizes the member name based on the host platform.    This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that SAS member names must follow these rules:    o can be up to 32 bytes in length (even if multi-byte characters are included)    o can include special characters, except the characters /\*?"<>|:-    o cannot contain any null bytes    o can begin with or contain any supported characters, excluding blanks    o must contain at least one character. An all-blank name is not permitted.    o trailing blanks will be trimmed    o can contain mixed-case letters; however, SAS normalizes the member name based on the host platform.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: VALIDMEMNAME=COMPATIBLE | COMPAT | EXTEND] 
    
Extends the characters that can be used in member names for SAS data sets, views, 
and item stores. This option extends the valid characters to: 

  o international characters 
  o characters supported by third-party databases 
  o characters commonly used in file names 
  
The VALIDMEMNAME= option allows users to control the characters allowed in member names.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that HTML (TAGSET.HTML4) is the default output destination in the SAS Windowing  environment on the Microsoft Windows and UNIX operating systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the LISTING destination is the default output destination.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the SAS registry settings determine the default destination setting. This  setting is HTML by default in SAS 9.3 in the SAS Windowing environment for the UNIX  and Microsoft Windows operating systems. HTML 4.0 is the HTML version supported by  default.   Note: In SAS 9.3, HTML output in the SAS Windowing environment is the default for  Microsoft Windows and UNIX, but not for other operating systems and not in batch mode.  When you run SAS in batch mode or on other operating systems, the LISTING destination  is open and is the default, ODS Graphics is not enabled by default, and the default  style for HTML output is Styles.Default.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: ODSDEST= HTML | LISTING | AUTO 

Changes the default ODS destination. In SAS 9.3, HTML is the default output destination 
for the SAS Windowing environment in the Microsoft Windows and UNIX operating systems. 
For all other platforms, LISTING is the default destination.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Enables ODS Graphics processing by default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Disables ODS graphics processing.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that the SAS registry setting determines the default destination setting.                 Note: In SAS 9.3, ODS Graphics is enabled in the SAS Windowing environment for Microsoft  Windows and UNIX, but not for other operating systems and not in batch mode. When you run  SAS in batch mode or on other operating systems, ODS Graphics is not enabled by default,  the LISTING destination is open and is the default, and the default style for HTML output  is Styles.Default.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: ODSGRAPHICS= ON | OFF | AUTO 

Controls ODS Graphics processing.

In SAS 9.3, ODS Graphics is enabled by default in the SAS Windowing environment for UNIX and 
Microsoft Windows. When ODS graphics processing is enabled, the graphs are integrated with 
tables and all output is displayed in the same HTML file using the HTMLBlue style. This new 
style is an all-color style, which is designed to integrate tables and modern statistical 
graphics. 

In SAS 9.3, when you run large computational programs, you might not want to create graphs. 
In those cases, you should disable ODS Graphics to improve the performance of your program. 
You can enable and disable ODS Graphics in your SAS programs with the ODS GRAPHICS OFF and 
ODS GRAPHICS ON statements. You can also change the ODS Graphics default in the Results tab. 

Prior to SAS 9.3, ODS Graphics was disabled by default.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the default style for ODS HTML destinations. For SAS 9.3, HTMLBlue is the  default style used for HTML output in the SAS Windowing environment for UNIX and  Microsoft Windows.   Note: By default, ODS displays the procedure or DATA step results in a style. The  TEMPLATE procedure creates and modifies styles. The Output Delivery System uses  these styles to produce customized formatted output.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the SAS registry setting determine the default style setting. In  SAS 9.3, HTMLBlue is the default style for the SAS Windowing environment on UNIX  and Microsoft Windows.   In HTML, the style impacts TABULAR and GRAPHICS output.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: ODSSTYLE= style-name | AUTO 
    
Specifies the default style to use.

Appends a value to the existing value of the specified system option.
    
Syntax: APPEND=(system-option-1 =argument-1 <system-option-n =argument-n>) 

Syntax Description:
system-option 
  can be AUTOEXEC, CMPLIB, FMTSEARCH, HELPLOC, MAPS, MSG, SASAUTOS, SASHELP, SASSCRIPT, or SET. 
  
  Note:Some of these options are available only when SAS starts. These options can be specified 
  in the APPEND= option only when the APPEND= option is specified in a configuration file or a 
  SAS command. 
  
argument 
  specifies a new value that you want to append to the current value of system-option. 
  argument can be any value that could be specified for system-option if system-option is set 
  using the OPTIONS statement.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the paper orientation as portrait. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the paper orientation as landscape.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the paper orientation as reverse portrait. Use this value to control the top  of the page relative to how the paper is inserted into the input paper tray.   REVERSEPORTRAIT can be used when you print preprinted or punched forms.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the paper orientation as reverse landscape. Use this value to control the top  of the page relative to how the paper is inserted into the input paper tray.   REVERSELANDSCAPE can be used when you print preprinted or punched forms.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: ORIENTATION=PORTRAIT | LANDSCAPE | REVERSEPORTRAIT | REVERSELANDSCAPE 

Specifies the paper orientation to use when printing to a printer.

Specifies to create a directory for a SAS library that is named in a LIBNAME statement 
if the directory does not exist.

Specifies not to create a directory for a SAS library that is named in a LIBNAME statement. 
    
This is the default.

Specifies that SAS attempts to automatically correct misspelled procedure names, 
misspelled procedure keywords, or misspelled global statement names. 

This is the default

Specifies that SAS does not automatically attempt to correct misspelled procedure names, 
misspelled procedure keywords, or misspelled global statement names.

For e-mail that is sent using the FILENAME statement EMAIL (SMTP) access method, 
specifies a UTC offset that is used in the Date header field of the e-mail message.
    
Syntax:
EMAILUTCOFFSET="+hhmm” | "-hhmm”

Syntax Description:
"+hhmm" | "-hhmm" 
  specifies the number of hours and minutes that are used as the UTC offset in the Date 
  header field of an e-mail. Use the UTC offset to establish the local time. 
  
  Requirement:The value of the EMAILUTCOFFSET= system option must be enclosed in double 
  or single quotation marks.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the argument to the URLENCODE function and to the URLDECODE function  is interpreted using the SAS session encoding. This is the default.   Note:SAS session encoding uses the URL encoding standard RFC 1738.   Tip:SESSION is compatible with previous releases of SAS.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the argument to the URLENCODE function and to the URLDECODE function  is interpreted using UTF-8 encoding.   Note:UTF-8 encoding uses the URL encoding standard RFC 3986.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: URLENCODING=SESSION | UTF8

Specifies whether the argument to the URLENCODE function and to the URLDECODE function 
is interpreted using the SAS session encoding or UTF-8 encoding.

Inserts the specified value as the first value of the specified system option.
    
Syntax:
INSERT=(system-option-1 =argument-1 <system-option-n =argument-n>) 

Syntax Description:
system-option 
  can be AUTOEXEC, CMPLIB, FMTSEARCH, HELPLOC, MAPS, MSG, SASAUTOS, SASHELP, SASSCRIPT, or SET. 
  
  Note:Some of these options are available only when SAS starts. These options can be 
  specified in the INSERT= option only when the INSERT= option is specified in a configuration 
  file or a SAS command. 
  
argument 
  specifies a new value that you want as the first value of system-option. 
  
  argument can be any value that could be specified for system-option if system-option 
  is set using the OPTIONS statement.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that no warning message is issued when the length of a variable that is being read  is larger than the length that is defined for the variable.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that a warning is issued when the length of a variable that is being read is larger  than the length that is defined for the variable. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that an error message is issued when the length of a variable that is being read  is larger than the length that is defined for the variable.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the type of message to write to the SAS log when the input data set is read 
using the SET, MERGE, UPDATE, or MODIFY statements.
Specifies whether to enable menus for Universal Printing and to set up printing defaults.
Displays in the SAS log the source location of the autocall macros when the autocall macro is compiled.

Specifies whether the macro processor prepends the full pathname of the autocall source file 
to the description field of the catalog entry of compiled auto call macro definition in the 
WORK.SASMACR catalog.
Enables the generation of coverage analysis data.
Specifies the location of the coverage analysis data file.
Specifies to write a byte order mark (BOM) prefix when a Unicode-encoded file is written to an external file.
Specifies not to write a BOM prefix when a Unicode-encoded file is written to an external file.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that SAS set the order as month, day, year.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that SAS set the order as month, year, day.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that SAS set the order as year, month, day.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that SAS set the order as year, day, month.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies that SAS set the order as day, month, year.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies that SAS set the order as day, year, month.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies that SAS set the order based on the value that corresponds to the LOCALE=  system option value and is one of the following: MDY | MYD | YMD | YDM | DMY | DYM.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: LOCALE=locale-name 

Specifies a set of attributes in a SAS session that reflect the language, local conventions, 
and culture for a geographical region. 

Required Argument:
locale-name 
  For a complete list of locale values (SAS names and POSIX names), see LOCALE= Values and 
  Default Settings for ENCODING, PAPERSIZE, DFLANG, and DATESTYLE Options.
Specifies to display a transcoding error when illegal values are read from a remote application.
Specifies not to display a transcoding error when illegal values are read from a remote application.

Syntax: STRIPESIZE=directory-path-1 size-1 <directory-path-2 size-2 …> 
    STRIPESIZE=(directory-path RESET) 
    
Syntax Description:
directory-path
  specifies an existing directory where the I/O page size for SAS data sets and utility files that 
  are created in this directory is set to size. Subdirectories of directory-path inherit the data 
  set or utility file size unless the STRIPESIZE= option has been set for the subdirectory.

Requirements:
If directory-path contains spaces, enclose the directory in quotation marks. 

directory-path must 
  be a valid Windows or UNIX FIle System (UFS) path. Native z/OS data set names are not supported.

  UNIX specifics:
  The casing used for directory-path must match the casing for the directory under UNIX operating 
  environments. 

size
  specifies the number of bytes in a RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) stripe, in multiples 
  of 1: 1,024 (kilo); 1,048,576 (mega); 1,073,741,824 (giga). For example, a value of 1024 specifies 
  1,024 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.
  Range: 1024–2147483648


RESET
  specifies to remove the directory from the value of the STRIPESIZE= option.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of utility file buffers to be allocated.  Range: 0–20
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of utility file buffers in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the number of utility file buffers in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the number of utility file buffers in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the number of utility file buffers as a hexadecimal value.  You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by an X.  For example, the value 0fx specifies 15 buffers.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the minimum number of utility file buffers to 0, which causes SAS to use the minimum optimal value  for the operating environment.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the number of utility file buffers to 20.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: UBUFNO=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX 
    
Specifies the number of buffers to use for utility files. 
    
Default: The shipped default is 0.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the utility file buffer size as a hexadecimal value.  You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the page size to 45 bytes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the utility file buffer size to 0. A value of 0 specifies that the buffer size is set to the  default page size for the operating environment.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the utility file buffer size to the maximum possible number in your operating environment,  up to the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is (2³¹)-1, or approximately 2 billion.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: UBUFSIZE=n| nK | nM | nG | nT |hexX | MIN | MAX]

Specifies the buffer size for utility files. 

Default: The shipped default is 0.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1 (bytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1,024 (kilobytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1,048,576 (megabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes).  Replace n with an integer value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the size of the view buffer as a hexadecimal value.  You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by an X. For example, the value 0fffeX specifies a buffer size of 65,534 bytes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Sets the size of the view buffer to 0.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Sets the size of the view buffer to (2⁶⁴⁻¹)-1, or approximately 9.2 quintillion bytes.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: UBUFSIZE=n| nK | nM | nG | nT |hexX | MIN | MAX]

Specifies the buffer size of the view buffer. 

Default: The shipped default is 65536.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the DATA step continues to execute without writing a message to the SAS log when  a variable is not initialized.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the DATA step continues to execute and writes a note to the SAS log when a variable  is not initialized.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: The SAS log when a variable is not initialized.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that the DATA step stops executing and writes an error message to the SAS log when  a variable is not initialized.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: VARINITCHK=NONOTE | NOTE | WARN | ERROR
    
Specifies whether a DATA step stops or continues executing when a variable is not initialized 
and the type of message to write to the SAS log.
Specifies that collecting data for the preservation of the SAS environment is enabled.
Specifies that collecting data for the preservation of the SAS environment is disabled.

Syntax: TIMEZONE='time-zone-name' | 'time-zone-ID' 
    
Specifies the user local time zone.
    
Syntax Descriptiont:
ime-zone-name
  specifies a three- or four-character time zone name. For example, EST is a time zone name 
  for Eastern Standard Time.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to convert and format decimal values by using the conversion methodology that is compatible  with releases prior to SAS 9.4. Use this option when SAS output might be processed by existing applications  that are sensitive to the details of formatting.   z/OS specifics: DECIMALCONV=COMPATIBLE is always in effect because z/OS uses the IBM hexadecimal floating-point number  representation rather than the IEEE format.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to convert and format decimal values by using the IEEE Standard for Floating-Point  Arithmetic 754-2008. Using the STDIEEE argument improves the accuracy and readability of  floating-point numbers. In some cases, more significant digits can be displayed in the same  field width.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: DECIMALCONV=COMPATIBLE | STDIEEE 
    
Specifies the binary to decimal conversion and formatting methodology.

Syntax: EMAILACKWAIT=number-of-seconds 

Specifies the number of seconds that SAS waits to receive an acknowledgment from an SMTP server.

Syntax Description:
number-of-seconds
  specifies the number of seconds that SAS waits to receive an acknowledgment from an SMTP server.

  Range: 0–3600

Syntax: COLOPHON="text-string" 
    
Specifies a text string that is embedded in a graphic file or a PDF that is created by Universal 
Printers. The text string is not displayed in the rendered graphic or PDF.

Syntax Description:
text-string
  specifies the text that is embedded in a graphic file.
  Length: up to 4,000 characters.
  Requirement: The text string must be enclosed in quotation marks.
  Interaction: Text strings that are longer than the value of the LRECL= option are truncated. 
    The default value of the LRECL= option is 32767. Temporarily increase the value of the LRECL= 
    option for longer text strings.
Specifies to automatically start the animation in the web page.

Specifies to display the first frame of the animation in the web page. The animated file is started 
by clicking

Syntax: SVGFADEIN=n 
    
Specifies the number of seconds for an SVG frame to fade into view.

Syntax Description:
n
  specifies the number of seconds for an SVG frame to fade into view. Valid values can be any 
  numeric representation (for example, .01, 5, or 6.5).

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that for each SVG frame that is fading in or out of view, the fading of frames overlaps  in the same time span.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that for each SVG frame that is fading in or out of view, the frame fades out after the  fade-out is complete. The next frame is a frame that is fading in.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: SVGFADEMODE=OVERLAP | SEQUENTIAL 
    
Specifies whether an SVG frame overlaps the previous frame or whether each frame is played 
sequentially when a frame is fading in and out.

Syntax: SVGFADEOUT=n 
    
Specifies the number of seconds for an SVG frame to fade out of view.

Syntax Description:
n
  specifies the number of seconds for an SVG frame to fade out of view. Valid values can be any 
  numeric representation (for example, .01, 5, or 6.5).
Specifies to enable the SVG magnify tool in SVG documents.
Specifies to disable the SVG magnify tool for all SVG documents.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Requests an enhanced file format in a newly created SAS data file that counts observations beyond  the 32-bit limitation. Although this SAS data file is created for an operating environment that  stores the number of observations with a 32-bit integer, the data file behaves like a 64-bit file  with respect to counters.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Determined by the long integer size for the operating environment. In operating environments with  a 32-bit integer, the maximum number is 231–1 or approximately two billion observations  (2,147,483,647). In operating environments with a 64-bit integer, the maximum number is 263–1  or approximately 9.2 quintillion observations.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: EXTENDOBSCOUNTER=YES | NO
    
Specifies whether to extend the maximum observation count in a new output SAS data file.

Syntax: CSTGLOBALLIB='location' 
    
Specifies the location of the SAS Clinical Standards Toolkit global standards library. 

Syntax Description:
'location'
  specifies the directory where the SAS Clinical Standards Toolkit global standards library 
  is located. If the directory contains spaces, enclose the directory in quotation marks.

Syntax: CSTSAMPLELIB='location' 
    
Specifies the location of the SAS Clinical Standards Toolkit sample library.

Syntax Description:
'location'
  specifies the directory where the SAS Clinical Standards Toolkit global sample library 
  is located. If the directory contains spaces, enclose the directory in quotation marks.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Enables the DATA step to execute in supported parallel environments.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Disables the DATA step from executing in supported parallel environments.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: DSACCEL=ANY | NONE 
    
Specifies whether the DATA step is enabled for parallel processing in supported environments.

Syntax: AUTHINFO='authinfo_file_path'  | CASAUTHINFO='authinfo_file_path'
    
Specifies a file where user ID and passwords are kept for authentication. 

authinfo_file_path
  specifies the path where an Authinfo file is located. The Authinfo file provides an alternative 
  to including passwords in programs. The most frequent use of this option is to submit code to 
  CAS from the command line, in batch mode.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the total number of bytes to read
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the total number of kilobytes to read.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the total number of megabytes to read.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the total number of gigabytes to read.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies that the entire file can be read, no matter how large it is.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: CASDATALIMIT=integer | integerK | integerM | integerG | ALL]
    
Specifies the maximum number of bytes of data that can transferred from the SAS Cloud Analytic Services server to SAS. 

Default: 100M

Tip:
This option can prevent you from accidentally transferring a large amount of data from the server to the client.

When you use the caslib all assign; statement to create CAS LIBNAME assignments for all defined caslibs, 
the default value of 100M is used as the maximum number of bytes that can be transferred from the CAS 
server to SAS.. To override this value, use the CASDATALIMIT= system option. 

In SAS Viya, you can limit the data transferred from the CAS server to SAS by using the DATALIMIT LIBNAME 
option or the DATALIMIT data set option.

Syntax: CASHOST="host-name"

Specifies the host name of CAS that is associated with a CAS session. 

Range: 256 characters 

Example:
OPTIONS CASHOST="rdcgrd001.unx.sas.com";

Syntax: CASLIB="name"
    
Specifies the caslib name for the session that is identified by the SESSREF= option.

Default: None
Range: 128 characters

Interaction:
The CAS statement session option CASLIB= overrides this option. For more information, see CASLIB= Session Option.

Note:
This option can be restricted by a site administrator.

Tip:
A best practice is to explicitly set options for a session using the CAS statement SESSOPTS= option. 
Here is an example:
  
  cas mysess sessopts=(caslib=mycaslib collate=UCA);

Syntax: CASNUMCHARMULTIPLIER=n
    
Specifies a multiplication factor that is used to increase the number of bytes for a fixed character 
variable when data is transcoded to the UTF-8 encoding in order to run in the CAS server.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to use all of the worker nodes.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the number of worker nodes to use. Replace <number> with an integer value ranging from 0 to 5000.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: CASNWORKERS= ALL | number 
    
Syntax Description:
ALL 
  specifies to use all of the worker nodes. 
number
  specifies the number of worker nodes to use. 
  In SMP mode, number is always 0, whether you set CASNWORKERS= to 0 or 1. 
  In MPP mode, specify number=0 to use the maximum number of worker nodes that are available. You can set 
    CASNWORKERS= to a number that is less than or equal to the maximum number of worker nodes. 
  Range: 0-5000

Syntax: CASPORT=port-number
    
Specifies the port to use when connecting to CAS. 

Default: 0
Range: 0 to 65535 

Example:
OPTIONS CASPORT=12345;

Syntax: CASSESSOPTS=(session-options) | SESSOPTS=(session-options) 

Specifies one or more CAS session options for the default CAS session. 

The following is a list of most of the session-options: 
  APPTAG= specifies the string to prefix to log messages.
  AUTOCORRECT= automatically corrects misspelled procedure names and keywords, and global statement names.
  CASLIB= specifies the caslib name to set as the active caslib.
  COMPOPT= specifies the type of code generation optimizations to use in the SAS language compiler.
  COLLATE= specifies the collating sequence for sorting.
  DATASTEPFMTERR= specifies how the DATA step reacts when SAS cannot find a specified variable format.
  DATASTEPMSGSUMLEVEL= specifies the DATA step message summary level.
  DATASTEPREPLACETABLE= specifies whether a DATA step can replace an existing table.   
  DATASTMTCHK= specifies which SAS statement keywords are prohibited from being specified as a one-level 
    DATA step name to protect against overwriting an input data set. 
  DKRICOND= specifies the error level to report when a variable is missing from an input data set during 
    the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.
  DKROCOND= specifies the error level to report when a variable is missing from an output data set during 
    the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option. 
  DQLOCALE specifies the default 5-letter SAS Quality Knowledge Base (QKB) ISO locale code to use as the 
    default locale for data quality (DQ) operations. 
  DQSETUPLOC specifies the name of the default SAS Quality Knowledge Base (QKB) to use for data quality operations.
  ERRORS= specifies the maximum number of observations for which SAS issues complete error messages. 
  EVENTDS specifies one or more data sets that define events.
  FMTCASLIB specifies the caslib where persisted format libraries are retained. 
  INVALIDDATA= specifies the value that SAS assigns to a variable when invalid numeric data is encountered.
  INTERVALDS specifies one or more interval-name=value pairs, where the value is the name of a data set that 
    contains user-defined intervals.
  LOCALE= specifies the locale to use for sorting and formatting.
  LOGFLUSHTIME= specifies the log flush time, in milliseconds. 
  MAXTABLEMEM= specifies the maximum amount of physical memory, in bytes, to allocate for a table.
  MESSAGELEVEL= specifies the log message level.
  METRICS= specifies whether to include detailed performance metrics reports in the SAS log. 
  NWORKERS= specifies the number of worker nodes for a new session.
  TIMEOUT= specifies the SAS Cloud Analytic Services session time-out in seconds for a new or existing session.
  TIMEZONE= specifies the time zone offset, in hours, from UTC.

Syntax: CASTIMEOUT=seconds
    
Specifies the CAS session time-out in seconds. The session time-out starts ticking when the number of 
connections to the session is zero.

Default: 60
Range: 0 to 99999999 

Example:
OPTIONS CASTIMEOUT=28800;

Syntax: CASUSER=user-ID 
    
Specifies the user ID to use when connecting to CAS. 

Default: no value 

Example:
OPTIONS CASUSER=saszzz ;
Specifies that by default, the DATA step runs in the CAS server.
Specifies that by default, the DATA step runs in SAS.
Syntax:

Syntax: CASINSTALL="physical-file"
    
Specifies installation location used to start CAS. 

Note: At a customer site, CASINSTALL is expected to be defined in an environment variable, CAS_INSTALL, 
that is set in the install scripts. Note: Alternatively, INSTALL= can be included in the specified 
SETUPFILE= when a server is started with PROC CASOPERATE. 

Range: 256 characters 

Example:
OPTIONS CASINSTALL="/opt/v9cas/laxnd/TKGrid";

Syntax: CASLIFETIME=duration 

Specifies the duration, in minutes, for a server to run. After the specified lifetime is exceeded, 
the server automatically shuts down. The CASLIFETIME= value is read during server start up. 

Range: 0 to 1000000 minutes
Default: 1000000 minutes 

Example:
OPTIONS CASLIFETIME=480; /* shut down the server after 8 hours */

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to include detailed performance metrics in the SAS log.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to exclude the detailed performance metrics from the SAS log.

Help.#cdata:
Syntax: CASLOGCNTL= METRICS | NOMETRICS 
    
Specifies the logging control for logging CAS actions. 

METRICS
  specifies to include detailed performance metrics in the SAS log.

NOMETRICS
  specifies to exclude the detailed performance metrics from the SAS log.

Syntax: SESSREF=reference-name |CASNAME=reference-name 
    
Indicates the default session name. This session name is used when creating a session if the creation 
request does not explicitly identify the session name. This session name is used to identify a session 
when a request does not explicitly identify the session name. 

Default: CASAUTO
Range: 256 characters 

Example:
OPTIONS SESSREF=mysessref;
OPTIONS CASNAME=mysessref;
Specifies to write messages to the SAS log if accessibility problems are found.

Specifies not to detect for accessibility problems or write accessibility problem
messages to the SAS log.

Specifies to create accessible ODS graphics by default.
    
Tip: When you specify the ACCESSIBLEGRAPH system option, you do not need
to set the ACCESSIBLE=YES option in the ODS HTML5 statement.
Specifies not to create accessible ODS graphics by default.

Specifies to create accessible graphs, by default, for the ODS PDF destination. 
    
Tip: When you set the ACCESSIBLEPDF system option, you do not need to set the
ACCESSIBLE option in the ODS PDF statement.
Specifies not to create accessible graphs for the ODS PDF destination.
Specifies to create accessible tables and reports by default.
Specifies not to create accessible tables and reports by default.
